title: A Detective, a Sidekick, and a Constable walk into a Turing machine: The Mind of the Maker
description:
Matt and I discuss the creative act of writing, particularly in the frame of detective stories, while contemplating Dorothy Sayers' book, The Mind of the Maker, which explores creativity. 
Dorothy Sayers' quote:
“For whatever reason God chose to make man as he is— limited and suffering and subject to sorrows and death—He had the honesty and the courage to take His own medicine. Whatever game He is playing with His creation, He has kept His own rules and played fair. He can exact nothing from man that He has not exacted from Himself. He has Himself gone through the whole of human experience, from the trivial irritations of family life and the cramping restrictions of hard work and lack of money to the worst horrors of pain and humiliation, defeat, despair and death. When He was a man, He played the man. He was born in poverty and died in disgrace and thought it well worthwhile.”

Great authors (and their detectives)
Rex Stout (Nero Wolfe)
Dorothy Sayers (Lord Peter Wimsey)
Josephine Tey (Alan Grant)
Agatha Christie (Miss Marple, Hercule Poirot)
Ellis Peters (Brother Cadfael)

At the border between order/chaos, known/unknown, one finds both infinite tension and infinite release - the partaking of a paradox.

Our desires are social, ends are many, not one. Like a detective working a room. The iconic detective is usually one stuck between recognition and repentance, on an edge, unable to move forward in his life.
The Trinitarian vision of writing a la Dorothy Sayers.
The Creative Idea (the first imagining of the work.)
The Creative Energy (the incarnating of the work, the writing it down)
The Creative Power (the meaning of the work, it being read)

The soul is always striving for the likeness. 
The mutual gift giving in marriage. The gift of attention.
